awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Development of a Stoichiometric, Direct-Injected, Soot-Free Engine for Heavy-Duty Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Diesel engines remain critical to global economies, but are under threat from increasingly-stringent emissions regulations. Many alternatives, like spark-ignition and electric vehicles, sacrifice some of the performance or range benefits of Diesel-style operation. This creates a market need for technologies that can maintain Diesel engine performance while remaining decoupled from the dirty emissions of Diesel fuel. This proposal centers on the development of the ?ClearFlame Combustion System? (CFCS): a novel combustion process that enables Diesel-style engines to combust low-carbon alternative fuels like ethanol and methanol without sacrificing the power possible with traditional Diesel combustion. Further, the sootless nature of alternative fuels such as methanol and ethanol obviates the need for a Diesel particulate filter, and enables stoichiometric air-fuel ratios to eliminate the need for selective catalytic reduction of NOx (smog). The engine technology has the potential to alter the dynamics of any market dominated by Diesel engines (including heavy-duty transportation, agriculture, rail, and power generation) and can be licensed to, or jointly developed with, OEMs for simple integration into their existing product lines. Phase I results have shown a 30% increase in engine torque at increased efficiency, while engine-out soot emissions are more than 100x lower than that of Diesel engines, falling under the 2010 EPA regulation limit without aftertreatment. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will continue development of the CFCS. The Phase I results showed that three critical CFCS subsystems?engine insulation, alcohol direct injection, and a combustion chamber optimized for stoichiometric combustion with exhaust gas load control?could be developed and integrated to achieve a previously unattainable combination of strong performance and low emissions. This Phase II effort will further advance these key components and demonstrate the benefits of the CFCS on a commercial engine platform, using CFD modeling and engine experiments to show the advantages of the CFCS compared to the Diesel baseline. The goal is to show how the CFCS enables a multi-cylinder heavy-duty engine to simultaneously improve power density by 30% at no loss of efficiency, while also achieving sootless stoichiometric exhaust conditions that are compatible with low-cost and highly-effective three-way catalysis (the same system that enables gasoline and natural gas engines to be much cleaner than Diesel). A Phase II prototype demonstration would realize a longtime industry goal of integrating three-way catalysis with a Diesel-style engine, allowing Diesel-style engines to achieve the emissions profile of the cleanest alternatives (like natural gas).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Heavy-duty trucks account for account for about 25% of total U.S. transportation sector energy consumption each year. Most of these vehicles are powered by compression ignition diesel fuel engines, which typically emit elevated levels of oxides of nitrogen, partially combusted hydrocarbons, and black particulate matter during operation. ClearFlame uses an innovative technology solution that modifies diesel combustion engines, allowing them to run on a wide variety of plant-based renewable fuels without sacrificing performance or increasing costs, while reducing greenhouse gas emissions and harmful pollutants including particulate matter, carbon monoxide, and NOx emissions.

 

The goal of this project was to demonstrate ClearFlame?s technology on a popular and widely used production heavy-duty diesel engine. Our initial focus was on ethanol because it is a clean and low-cost fuel that is readily available today. During this project, ClearFlame successfully matched the torque and power output of the diesel engine across the entire operating range, thereby validating our technology and our value proposition. Exhaust gas analysis revealed particulate matter levels low enough to pass EPA regulations without a diesel particulate filter. Engine-out levels of smog were comparable to that of its diesel sibling, indicating that the same exhaust after-treatment of the stock diesel could be employed in the ethanol engine also.

 

Ethanol is produced in the US from locally grown feedstocks and enhances our energy security by reducing overall demand and reliance on oil imports. Ethanol also keeps revenues in the US, supporting rural economies when they need it most. There is also overwhelming scientific consensus that ethanol offers a 45% reduction in CO2 among other benefits. By equipping heavy-duty engines to run on ethanol, ClearFlame?s technology offers the greatest carbon reduction potential today for a variety of end-use applications including on-road trucking, farm tractors, mining vehicles and stationary gensets.

 

ClearFlame?s technology is already empowering fleets with class 8 semi-trucks to evaluate heavy-duty diesel engine operation on 100% renewable plant-based fuels. The agricultural sector has also recognized the potential for ClearFlame?s combustion system to drive rapid decarbonization, and the power generation sector has shown interest in our technology to reduce operating costs and slash emissions at the same time. Our strong focus on these hard-to-electrify ?dirty diesel? applications is expected to yield major reductions in greenhouse emissions and pollution in the years to come. While EV and fuel cell trucks are on the horizon, their adoption is proving to be more challenging than expected, and we simply cannot wait. Those solutions also do not go far enough on their own, making ClearFlame?s rapidly implementable technology a very credible path to a low-carbon future.

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2023
Modified by: Julie Blumreiter

    ClearFlame Engine Technologies
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Julie Blumreiter
    ClearFlame Engine Modifications

    ClearFlame Engine Technologies
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Julie Blumreiter
    ClearFlame Alcohol Powered Truck
  • ClearFlame's Co-Founders, BJ Johnson (CEO) and Julie Blumreiter (CTO) stand in front of one of the company's converted trucks, which run on 100% low-carbon alternative fuel.
    ClearFlame Engine Technologies
